fons1107: This is so beautiful. Love to you!
kitty_whiskerson: I’d like to honour the younger me in the moment I decided I wasn’t going to let myself die. The exact moment at 15 years old laying on a mattress on the floor in the only corner of my dingy apartment that didn’t leak that I worked nights to pay for while putting myself through high school. That moment, soaked in my own tears and wanting to disappear, I decided to live and I decided that I wouldn’t just live, I’d make my life something special. That tough 15 year old is now 38 and I’m so glad she lived because she grew into a woman who believed she can and believes that every other queer woman can, and will be great.

gwenniemack: You are so blessed to have each other
celestialsunflower_: You are incredibly inspirational in a myriad of ways. I ended middle school & began high school tending to my mother who had breast cancer at the time. I was her caregiver & my younger siblings part-time parent as my Dad had moved out two years prior (divorce), while still trying to do me at 15. Now at 22, I’m learning to be grateful for my parents marriage and divorce & my mother’s illness in a new light, rather than feel like it took something away from me, it feels like I was given a gift of perspectives. I would like to honor the memory of those days that I felt like I was never permitted to be a child, like my mother didn’t deserve to lose a marriage, all of her hair & two breasts at once; like my Dad was to blame for so many things; though it was some of most dark & trying days, it was the most fertile ground for growth to find the light and gratitude in it all. I no longer blame, or “why me?” days away. Thank you for being open and for sharing. Thank you for making a space for us to open and share. Thank you for being you. Sending you all the love I possibly can thru this lil screen 💓

labruxapg: I learn so much from reading your words everyday. Open heart and letting light in at its finest. I honor you today (and always). ...and, Eb is a m@gical star.
bananabenny: I always take the day I lost my first pregnancy to reflect and remember my journey to motherhood. I think our society sells a narrative that conception/pregnancy/motherhood are all the most natural things a woman can do and so they come naturally and simply and elegantly. It took 2 years and dozens of invasive tests for me to get pregnant and then it was gone. I think I almost mourned the loss of that idyllic narrative as much as the loss of the baby. When I got pregnant again, I was so afraid and sad and still grieving. And then I had my baby and spent months trying to connect and feel that lightning bolt of love everyone tells you you’re supposed to feel. I realize now that my love for my child came like my love for my husband. It built as I got to know my baby as a person and now 2 years later, he is the light of my life. Anyway, I take that day every year to remind myself that letting go of narratives, letting go of the “should,” is painful and in its own way a death. But from that can come the biggest love.

dirtylola: I am trying to do that now. I don’t want the messy pettiness that it can turn into. I also know that all I can do is keep my side of the street clean. It has been hard. It takes strength to move through this pain and the carelessness of those around me with my head held high and eyes on the light at the end of this dark tunnel. Thank you for being a guide through all of this by sharing your journey through the pain.
